Trending: Julianne Moore is “Gloria Bell,” opening in Boston and a veritable tour de force for the Oscar-winning actress who is in virtually every scene for this mostly affectionate portrait of a 50something divorcee. A grandmother and very much on her own, Gloria’s passion extends beyond her job, her two grown children. It’s on the dance floor at a local bar where disco classics prompt her to let loose that she feels most alive. It’s here that whenever she gets knocked down, Gloria finds the guts, the strength, to pick herself up, embrace the present, look to the future. It’s a life lesson Moore herself learned early in her brilliant career. This past week at Manhattan’s Langham Place Hotel I mentioned how for the first time since it opened, I had recently rewatched Andrew Davis’ classic thriller, 1993’s “The Fugitive.” Time has been kind to “The Fugitive,” a gigantic Harrison Ford hit that spawned not a sequel but a spin-off “U.S. Marshals” with Tommy Lee Jones. What really surprised me? Moore’s star billing, right below the two male leads. At the time she was known for a scene-stealing role in “The Hand That Rocks the Cradle.” How did she get that top spot for a relatively small role? Was it simply a good agent? “Because it was a big part,” Moore explained. “I tested for it. It was going to be a big part — he [Ford’s wrongly accused Dr. Richard Kimble] would meet me at the hospital and I was going to go on the run with him. Two weeks before shooting, they made a decision to cut that part from the movie. It was devastating. Because this was my big break! It was a really big deal. Instead I showed up and worked for those few days — and that was it. I had the billing but I didn’t have the part. Honestly, how did I feel? I was devastated. Sometimes that happens.” Q: Like Gloria, you had to say it doesn’t matter and you go on? JULIANNE MOORE: You can’t say it doesn’t matter, that’s the thing. But you have to go on. That’s the difference – resiliency is stuff happens, you feel it, it is painful. It does matter. But you still go on. A Julianne Moore feature runs in the HERALD next week. Francis Ford Coppola Intros 50th Anniversary Edition of Mario Puzo’s ‘The Godfather’ Francis Ford Coppola will be forever defined by his “Godfather” trilogy, whose first installment in 1972 was a notoriously troubled production. Its spectacular success rebooted Marlon Brando’s career, made stars of Al Pacino, James Caan, John Cazale and Robert Duvall and paved the way for many, many Mafioso movies to come, including “The Sopranos.” But first, to start our enduring fascination with the Mob, there was Mario Puzo’s 1969 bestseller. In an Introduction written specifically for this 50th Anniversary edition ($16, Berkley), Coppola refers to his lackluster school days (“I was a perpetually bad student”) who’d been “temporarily paralyzed by polio.” He recalls a thuggish Italian brute coming up to him as he was riding high on the initial success of “The Godfather” and snarling at him regarding Puzo, “You didn’t make him!! He made you!” Coppola won’t disagree: Puzo’s novel, he writes, “changed my life.” Although he does confess his first impression reading Puzo was “This was more like Harold Robbins or Irving Wallace” – best-selling authors of what today would be derided as “popcorn novels,” entertaining but hollow. When it became apparent Coppola would adapt Puzo’s book for a movie, a re-reading offered a discovery: “Lurking within it was a great story,” he writes, “almost classical in nature: That of a king with three sons, each of whom had inherited an aspect of his personality.” The filmmaker recalls Puzo’s handwritten notes on Coppola’s script – “He was terse.” He mentions the Italy-set saga of Vito Andolini who came to America after the brutal killings of his father and mother – a key chapter that Coppola could not insert into “Godfather” but became the subtitled Robert De Niro sequence in “The Godfather, Part II.” Coppola writes that he was irritated that “The Godfather, Part III” was so titled when he and Puzo thought of it not as the conclusion of a trilogy but “a coda” that should have been called “The Death of Michael Corleone.” He happily credits Puzo with coming up with that film’s most memorable line: “Just when I thought I was out, they pull me back in.” Coppola concludes, “The more familiar I became with Mario’s work, the more impressed I was.” It may be 50 years on but it’s not too late – check out Puzo’s “The Godfather” and see for yourself. Brilliant Brit Crime Drama “Manhunt” Martin Clunes is the British actor best known for the wry, offbeat, long-running “Doc Martin,” so it’s quite a switch as he commands serious attention in “Manhunt,” a true-crime British miniseries premiering Monday on Acorn.TV. Based on the memoirs of London Metropolitan police detective DCI Colin Sutton, who co-wrote the series, “Manhunt” is an extremely well-paced procedural that begins with the investigation into the death of a visiting French student Amelie Delagrange whose body is found on Twickenham Green in August 2004. The Green is open, bordered by shops and restaurants, yet there are no witnesses. There is no motive and while there has been no sexual assault, the killer was careful to leave no forensic evidence. Clunes’ DCI Sutton is not thought the best man for this job where the public demands they find the killer. His subordinates are hardly a happy bunch when Sutton’s directives mean a mountain of drudgery going thru hundreds and hundreds of hours of CCTV footage or the license plates of every registered car. A connection is discovered with the murders of two other young women and there’s a sighting of a suspicious man dumping into a nearby canal – it’s a corpse. Finally, as months pass the police get a break with the video footage. Once Sutton is certain they’ve found the killer, he must collect enough evidence for a conviction. Clunes is best when unexpected grace notes appear, as when he goes to Paris to not just comfort Amelie’s grieving parents but to apologize – for if the police had not screwed up on discovering a crucial clue, the killer would have been stopped earlier and Amelie would be alive. NEW DVDs: Eric Dane is retired as “The Last Ship: The Complete Fifth Season” (Blu-ray + Digital, Warner Bros. Home Entertainment, Not Rated) begins its final 10-episode season. With Michael Bay among its executive producers, this apocalyptic drama emphasizes action and moral quandaries among its crew as a lone naval warship the USS Nathan James patrols the seas to save humanity from extinction after the Red Flu, a powerful virus, has decimated Earth’s population. Dane’s Tom Chandler remains central to the action as the ship’s crew tries to avert another world war. Bonus: two featurettes. A novel look at Superman’s origins, the hit SYFY series “Krypton: The Complete First Season” (Blu-ray + Digital, Warner Bros. Home Entertainment, Not Rated) begins two generations before the Faster than a Speeding Bullet resident alien lands on Earth. Here Superman’s grandfather Seg-El bonds with a time traveling Earthling Adam Strange to restore the fate of his future grandson. Cameron Cuffe’s Seg-El is the big reason this “Krypton” flies high. Extras abound: Gag reel, deleted scenes, the 2017 Comic.Con panel and featurettes. Jesse Eisenberg is the executive producer on the fascinating documentary “The World Before Your Feet” (DVD, Greenwich, Not Rated) and as a DVD bonus, there’s an interview with him along with deleted scenes. But the focus here is on two men. There’s Matt Green, whose odyssey is the point of the film. Behind the camera is Jeremy Workman as director, producer, cinematographer and editor. “World Before Your Feet” details Green’s quixotic life-changing journey. Namely, to walk the 8,000 miles of roads and paths that comprise New York City. Green left his engineering job and his apartment, devised a $15 per day budget and couch surfed and cat-sat to be able to continue on his peculiar trek. From Staten Island thru all five boroughs, from parks, streets, cemeteries and bridges, Green learns about his city and offers,according to The Hollywood Reporter, an “endearing” look at the “pleasure of wandering.” A three-hour WWII epic that stands as the most expensive Finnish film yet made, “Unknown Soldier” (Blu-ray, Kino Lorber, Not Rated) covers three years in the life and death(s) of an infantry unit in what was known as the Finnish Continuation War. In Finnish with English subtitles, the extensive bonus material includes deleted scenes, ‘Into the Unknown: The Making of “Unknown Soldier”’ and post-production featurettes. By Brian Douglass Do you have a point you’d like to make or an issue you feel strongly about? Submit a letter to the editor or a guest column. The city of Bend government is in crisis. The most egregious act against democracy in the history of Bend, has been committed over the filling of a vacant council position by Sally Russell and Bruce Abernethy. Not in my nearly 30 years as a volunteer disability rights advocate and community activist have I seen an elected public official sworn in and then within a month virtually self-destruct and lose all their credibility and trust with their constituents. However, that is what we all have witnessed with our new mayor, Sally Russell. Do you have a point you’d like to make or an issue you feel strongly about? Submit a letter to the editor or a guest column. She must be censored, sanctioned, or reprimanded by the Deschutes County Democratic Party and likely face a recall, after she has served six months in office. My several failed attempts to engage the Deschutes County Democratic Party, indicate that the party has decided to “circle the wagons” around Russell. Running as a “progressive” and fully supported by the Deschutes County Democratic Party, Russell dismayed voters by voting for a white, male Republican, to fill her remaining two years on the Bend City Council. Russell betrayed her supporters by supporting a candidate heavily promoted and lobbied for, by the Bend special interest group consisting of the Bend Chamber, Central Oregon Builders, Central Oregon Realtors and Russell, prior to her vote. Russell, as a Democrat, would certainly prefer another progressive. Apparently, she could not find a suitable choice, in the field of 36 candidates who applied for the appointment. Councilor Bill Moseley, a Republican, would certainly have preferred a conservative that had the blessing of the Bend special interest group. That would be understandable. Elections have consequences, as we all know. Voters defeated Moseley for mayor and Andrew Davis and Sarah McCormick and their $100K campaign for council. Yet in a flash, Russell thwarted the demonstrated will of the people, by supporting a special interest candidate; Abernethy then followed Russell’s lead. The “ideological balance” on the council with four progressives and three conservatives which was commonly in place for the past several years, and was publicly preferred, and with Russell’s and Abernethy’s votes the “ideological balance” became five conservatives and two progressives. Unbelievable! There can be no doubt by the votes of Russell and Abernethy that they will ever vote with the two progressive’s remaining on the council. They simply should not be trusted again. The important and needed progressive ideas to benefit average, hard-working Bend residents pursuing the American dream is what is needed to move forward, such as a reform of the council governance model, the $15 living wage, affordable housing, “starter homes” on unclassified lands south of Bend, a light rail system and Net Zero Energy (Solar) program all would improve the quality of life for many residents. It is hard to imagine with the current five conservatives and two progressives, that any of these ideas will see the light of day. All through the campaign Russell spoke to the need for “collaboration” on the council. She then became a “collaborator” aligned with special interest groups, when it came time to fill the council vacancy. I believe that both Russell and Abernethy should resign their positions immediately. Voters must wait six months prior to a recall campaign against Russell. Chris Piper, who received the interim appointment, is severely compromised and should also resign immediately. A blue ribbon nonpartisan commission should be formed to guide the city through to a smooth and orderly transition process. Bend cannot afford and should not have to wait two to four years to rectify this travesty and breach of the public trust and a new election should occur in the May primary election. Russell as the first elected mayor in 90 years, should now become the first mayor in Bend history to be recalled by the voters. — Brian Douglass lives in Bend. Firefighters stand back as smoke pours out of a window at a house fire on Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday evening. Firefighters stand back and assess the best way to get under the house and put out the remaining embers of a house fire on Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday night. QUEENSBURY — Six fire departments were called into action Wednesday night in response to a fire that destroyed a home at 77 Gregwood Circle. The fire at the home in the Forest Park mobile home park was first called in around 5:45 p.m. West Glens Falls Fire Department First Assistant Chief Michael Gordon said everyone was out of the house before his team arrived and there were no injuries. Fire crews remained on the scene until around 10 p.m. Firefighters dug their way under the home from the front side to get at remnants of the fire underneath the house. Several panels and windows were removed in order to pump smoke out of the home. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, according to Gordon. Bill Barber, a brother of one of the residents, said the residents recently had electrical work done and he thought the fire may be related to that. He said when they returned home and plugged in appliances, something sparked and caught fire. Gordon said cold weather, such as the near single digits on Wednesday night, makes fighting fires much more difficult. He said frozen water lines and hoses can back things up, and several firefighters said their gloves were frozen in the frigid temperatures. There were no water lines close to the home, so several tanker trucks were needed to shuttle in water. The assisting departments included West Glens Falls, South Queensbury, Queensbury Central, Bay Ridge, Corinth and South Glens Falls. Fire crews remained on the scene until around 10 p.m. Firefighters dug their way under the home from the front side to get at remnants of the fire underneath the house. Several panels and windows were removed in order to pump smoke out of the home. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, according to Gordon. Texas High School theatre students advanced to the bi-district level after being named one of the top three schools during the University Interscholastic League 5A-District 15 One-Act Play Competition, which was held March 5 in Sulphur Springs, Texas. The students performed "The Crucible," written by Arthur Miller. Emma Daniel and Andrew Davis were named All Star Cast members. Addison Cross received All Star Cast Honorable Mention and Molly Kyles received the Tech Honor Crew Award. Cast and crew members include: Paisley Allen, Abby Cannon, Alex Cope, Jeremy Creek, Addison Cross, Emma Daniel, Andrew Davis, Shelby Davis, Beth Dietze, Nadia Fryer, Lia Graham, Rachel Johnson, Salem Karr, Molly Kyles, Juan Pena-Garcia, Connor Powell, Alec Rommel, Cate Rounds, Sam Sanchez, Miracle Shephard, Ryan Shupe and Davis Sutton. The THS UIL One-Act Play was under the direction of Lisa Newton, Trent Hanna, Amy Kemp and Bonnie Flieder. (Gallery photos by Andrew Davis Tucker/UGA) What better way to learn about ecology than conducting a study in a living lab at the University of Georgia’s State Botanical Garden of Georgia? For a semester-long stream project, UGA students in Ecology 3500 designed their own original studies involving observing and measuring ecological processes in the Orange Trail stream at the botanical garden, a UGA Public Service and Outreach unit. They conducted field research this week. “Specifically the students study macroinvertebrate communities in the stream and tend to look at different abiotic factors that influence their abundance and/or diversity,” said Katie Brownson, doctoral candidate in Integrative Conservation and Ecology, the lead teaching assistant for the course. “But there is a lot of variability in what they study, as the students design their own projects.” Ecology 3500, or simply titled “Ecology,” in the Odum School of Ecology introduces students to core principles, classic experiments, current events and ongoing research in ecology. Students learn to apply principles of ecology to evaluate the structure and function of the natural world, including how ecological processes shed light on human-environment interactions. Course lab activities use inquiry-based learning, which provides a more realistic experience of ecological research than traditional lab format. Working in teams, students design an original ecological study and collect, analyze, and present their data. 
Link: https://news.uga.edu/ecology-students-use-botanical-garden-as-living-lab/

New inspection policies in place for rental properties Megan Behnke, News WriterMarch 7, 2019Filed under News, Spotlight The Oshkosh City Council approved a new amended program for inspections on rental properties. It started March 1 and raised prices for landlords if any violations are found. Oshkosh Mayor Steve Cummings said the whole goal has been to ensure that people have clean and safe housing. “It’s been going on for a couple years,” Cummings said. “The legislatures in Madison gave communities the ability to focus on ‘Targeted Areas’ and bad rental properties.” Inspection Services Division for the City of Oshkosh Chief Building Official John Zarate said the new program and the previous program have two differences. “The program is not required to be enforced city-wide as required under the previous law by the state of Wisconsin,” Zarate said. “A fee cannot be charged for initial and follow-up inspection as long as violations are corrected within 30 days.” OshkoshLiving rental property owner Mark Neubauer said inspections shouldn’t change too much now that the new program is in place. “We just have to make sure that all the houses are up to code,” Neubauer said. “The only thing that’s really changing is if a rental property is found to have a violation, it will cost more to pay that fine, whether or not the property is being rented.” Cummings said the inspections won’t affect students/residents already renting apartments as much as it’ll affect the landlords. “The inspections are more for the landlords,” Cummings said. “If they see something wrong, they try to make you pay for it, trying to intimidate the students.” Zarate said programs are typically not updated each year. “The reason this program has had to undergo changes is that many landlords throughout the state are against this type of program, and they have tried to get laws to stop it,” Zarate said. “So when the laws get changed then the city has to adjust the program accordingly.” Neubauer said the advice he would give to students-residents renting any kind of property is to take care of it. “Treat your rental property like it’s your own home, because it is,” Neubauer said. “Be sure that everything is how it should be: appliances work, the walls are good, the windows are good, electricity, you shouldn’t have a problem.” Cummings said landlords should try to keep their properties in good condition in order to avoid getting a violation and that residents should take pictures of their place when they move in. “Whatever you’re paying, you’re expecting it to have proper heat, running water, etc.,” Cummings said. “Something could go wrong, something could break or a pipe burst, a window could be smashed and the landlord can ask students to leave, accusing them of something that they might’ve not done. Take pictures when you move in so you’re not hit with something that isn’t your fault.” Zarate said there is no cost to the tenant at any time for the inspection, and the inspection is voluntary. “If the tenants allow for the inspection of the rental unit, it will ensure that the unit meets minimum housing standards that the landlord is required to provide to a renter in Oshkosh,” Zarate said. “The standards cover health and safety items to make sure tenants have a safe and healthy place to live.” News RUB hosts 70th Winter Carnival with 90s theme News What are sororities and fraternities? Updated: March 11, 2019 @ 5:11 pm One firefighter feeds a hose to another underneath the house to put the final embers out of a fire at 77 Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday evening. Firefighters stand back as smoke pours out of a window at a house fire on Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday evening. Firefighters stand back and assess the best way to get under the house and put out the remaining embers of a house fire on Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday night. reporter - Education One firefighter feeds a hose to another underneath the house to put the final embers out of a fire at 77 Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday evening. Firefighters stand back as smoke pours out of a window at a house fire on Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday evening. Firefighters stand back and assess the best way to get under the house and put out the remaining embers of a house fire on Gregwood Circle in Queensbury on Wednesday night. QUEENSBURY — Six fire departments were called into action Wednesday night in response to a fire that destroyed a home at 77 Gregwood Circle. The fire at the home in the Forest Park mobile home park was first called in around 5:45 p.m. West Glens Falls Fire Department First Assistant Chief Michael Gordon said everyone was out of the house before his team arrived and there were no injuries. Fire crews remained on the scene until around 10 p.m. Firefighters dug their way under the home from the front side to get at remnants of the fire underneath the house. Several panels and windows were removed in order to pump smoke out of the home. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, according to Gordon. Bill Barber, a brother of one of the residents, said the residents recently had electrical work done and he thought the fire may be related to that. He said when they returned home and plugged in appliances, something sparked and caught fire. Gordon said cold weather, such as the near single digits on Wednesday night, makes fighting fires much more difficult. He said frozen water lines and hoses can back things up, and several firefighters said their gloves were frozen in the frigid temperatures. There were no water lines close to the home, so several tanker trucks were needed to shuttle in water. The assisting departments included West Glens Falls, South Queensbury, Queensbury Central, Bay Ridge, Corinth and South Glens Falls. Fire crews remained on the scene until around 10 p.m. Firefighters dug their way under the home from the front side to get at remnants of the fire underneath the house. Several panels and windows were removed in order to pump smoke out of the home. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, according to Gordon. "Victor Hugo said so long as there is poverty in the world, this story will have meaning." Victor Hugo's Les Misérables may have been written centuries ago, but the novel's themes of forgiveness, compassion, and love are as relevant in 2019 as they were in 1862. "Les Misérables does have an extraordinary resonance with people," actor Dominic West says in a new exclusive clip previewing the Masterpiece PBS series in which he plays Jean Valjean, a prisoner in the early 19th-century condemned for stealing bread to feed his family. "Victor Hugo said so long as there is poverty in the world, this story will have meaning." David Oyelowo, who portrays West's on-screen adversary Inspector Javert, agrees. "Les Miserables represents redemption, the ability to forgive, things that I think make it feel very resonant to an audience." In the sneak peek of the upcoming adaptation, it's clear the cast understands that most people's touchpoint for this story is the Les Miserables musical, be it the stage version, or Tom Hooper's 2012 film starring Hugh Jackman, Anne Hathaway, and Russell Crowe. While the new mini-series doesn't have songs, it does offer, as writer Andrew Davis put it, a "richer sense of the characters." "So many people associate Les Mis with the musical, but the original is a novel, and it's all drama," explains Lily Collins, who plays the ill-fated Fantine. "This rendition you really get to see the polarities much more. You see Fantine at her most vibrant, which is a perfect comparison then to when she's at her worst." Watch the sneak peek above. Les Misérables premieres Sunday, April 14 at 9 p.m. ET on Masterpiece PBS.

Callum Burroughs, provided by Reuters A senior Barclays executive claimed he wouldn't sacrifice himself to save the jobs of then CEO John Varley and former president Bob Diamond if capital-raising negotiations at the height of the financial crisis fell apart, a London jury heard today. "Well fuck that, I’m not taking a hit to save John and Bob’s jobs. Fuck that," the court heard that Roger Jenkins said. The quote from the former executive chairman of investment management in the Middle East and North Africa came in written testimony to the Serious Fraud Office by former Barclays Capital executive Richard Boath, in 2o14. The implication is that Jenkins was afraid the deal might be toxic enough to generate legal consequences that would land on his doorstep. The executives believed, during the darkest part of the global financial crisis, that if they failed to persuade a set of Qatari investors to give them £4 billion then Barclays might collapse. Other banks — Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns and Northern Rock — had gone to the wall at the time. The SFO alleges that Varley and other executives — Boath, Thomas Kalaris, and Roger Jenkins — misled investors in the deal by using "advisory services agreements" (ASAs). The SFO alleges that the side-deals paid Qatari companies £322 million ($423 million) — a 3.25% commission — in fees during the capital raisings, which were fraudulently not disclosed to other investors. The defendants have pleaded not guilty to all charges. Bob Diamond is not accused of any wrongdoing. Jenkins received a £25 million bonus for his role in the fundraising, given his close relationship with the Qatari investors. During a conversation between Jenkins and Boath in 2008, the two executives discussed the viability of paying Qatari investors additional fees, adding up to a larger sum than other investors received, the court heard. Boath said: "We can’t do a capital markets transaction where we give one set of fees to the market or to one set of investors, and ... have a different set of economics for another set of investors because if they found out they’ll go completely nuts. You can’t do that." The interview with the SFO indicates that there were numerous discussions about the way in which the Qataris could be paid, with Boath at one point getting frustrated by the prospect of an ASA being used. "Tell them to get stuffed. Let’s do something else," the jury heard. Read more: See all our coverage of the Barclays Qatar trial here. Previously, the court heard that Thomas Kalaris, formerly head of Barclays Wealth Management said, "None of us wants to go to jail here." He was referring to a draft of the agreement. Boath responded, "it ain't worth it and apparently the food sucks." Kalaris then added: "No the food sucks and the sex is worse." In his interview with the SFO, Boath made it clear that there "wasn’t a genuine concern about going to jail at all," and that his conversation with Kalaris was simply "a joke." He also claimed that his anxiety about the ASA deal "disappeared" after he learned that senior bank executives had consulted external legal advice about the agreements and the services provided. "How could senior people at the top of their profession at a global bank like Barclays have agreed to this without some verification of the services?" Boath said. The trial at Southwark Crown court is ongoing.
